data.value: Minimize a function over a given range by brute force.
Uses the "brute force" method, i.e., computes the function's value at each point of a multidimensional grid of points, to find the global minimum of the function.
The function is evaluated everywhere in the range with the datatype of the first call to the function, as enforced by the
NumPy function. The value and type of the function evaluation returned when
are affected in addition by the
argument (see Notes).
The brute force approach is inefficient because the number of grid points increases exponentially - the number of grid points to evaluate is
. Consequently, even with coarse grid spacing, even moderately sized problems can take a long time to run, and/or run into memory limitations.
The objective function to be minimized. Must be in the form
, where
is the argument in the form of a 1-D array and
is a tuple of any additional fixed parameters needed to completely specify the function.
Each component of the
tuple must be either a "slice object" or a range tuple of the form
. The program uses these to create the grid of points on which the objective function will be computed. See
for more detail.
Any additional fixed parameters needed to completely specify the function.
Number of grid points along the axes, if not otherwise specified. See
If True, return the evaluation grid and the objective function's values on it.
An optimization function that is called with the result of brute force minimization as initial guess.

*Note 1*: The program finds the gridpoint at which the lowest value of the objective function occurs. If

is None, that is the point returned. When the global minimum occurs within (or not very far outside) the grid's boundaries, and the grid is fine enough, that point will be in the neighborhood of the global minimum.
However, users often employ some other optimization program to "polish" the gridpoint values, i.e., to seek a more precise (local) minimum near
best gridpoint. The
function's
option provides a convenient way to do that. Any polishing program used must take
output as its initial guess as a positional argument, and take
input values for
as keyword arguments, otherwise an error will be raised. It may additionally take
and/or
as keyword arguments.
assumes that the

is the minimizing value of the argument,
is the minimum value of the objective function, "..." may be some other returned values (which are not used by

is the status code of the
program.
Note that when
is not None, the values returned are those of the
program, *not* the gridpoint ones. Consequently, while
confines its search to the input grid points, the
program's results usually will not coincide with any gridpoint, and may fall outside the grid's boundary. Thus, if a minimum only needs to be found over the provided grid points, make sure to pass in
